What is the relationship between Congress granting broad discretionary powers to federal agencies and the incumbency advantage enjoyed by congressme
How can Congress curb the discretionary powers given to federal agencies?

At least in modern times, the "big government" vs "small government" debate in this country is overwhelmingly a myth.  Ninety-nine percent of the time, the only real issue is what the government's PRIORITIES are.  If the priorities happen to be things in line with benefiting regular Americans (e.g. health care, public education, etc.), talking heads on TV, etc. will warn their viewers about the dangers of "bigger government."  But if we spend hundreds of billions (or more) bailing out Wall Street Banks, prosecuting decades-long wars for reasons that never really get explained, mysteriously, these things don't fall under the umbrella of "big government."
